channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Fetterman’s Debate Showing Raises Democratic Anxieties in Senate Battle
item.description: The Democratic nominee’s performance in Pennsylvania thrust questions of health to the center of a pivotal Senate race, adding uncertainty to the contest and worrying some in his party.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Lerer and Katie Glueck
item.media:credit: Caroline Gutman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Disability advocates and doctors praised Lt. Gov. John Fetterman for his debate appearance and noted that his speech did not reflect any cognitive impairment, but some Democrats worried that ordinary voters might see it differently.

item.title: Does the Constitution Guarantee a Right to Vote?
item.description: For decades, the courts and Congress have taken the lead in expanding the legal right to vote, but the founders never explicitly included it.
item.dc:creator: Michael Wines
item.media:credit: Jonah Markowitz for The New York Times
item.media:description: Various constitutional amendments prohibit denying voting rights to women, racial minorities and other groups. But the Constitution contains no explicit right to vote.

item.title: In Malliotakis vs. Rose Rematch, a Democrat Diverges From Party Orthodoxy
item.description: The race between Representative Nicole Malliotakis, a Republican, and Max Rose, a Democrat, is a rare look at how national political campaign themes are playing in New York.
item.dc:creator: Michael Gold
item.media:credit: Ahmed Gaber for The New York Times
item.media:description: Max Rose has attempted to separate himself from Democratic orthodoxy, even as he tries to reclaim his former seat from Ms. Malliotakis, the Republican incumbent.

item.title: Russia Intensifies Its Propaganda Campaign Against Ukraine
item.description: A new push by the Kremlin frames the war as a counterterrorism operation and seeks to rally Russians to support the fight, officials and researchers say.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times
item.media:description: A priest blessed new military enlistees at a recruiting office in Moscow this month. By framing Ukraine as the potential nuclear aggressor, Russia can ratchet up tensions over escalating the war without incurring the wrath of its population or further undermining support for President Vladimir V. Putin.

item.title: The Young Woman Behind a Last Mystery of the Green River Killer
item.description: A mother lost her daughter 40 years ago. Until investigators knocked on her door, she had no idea what had happened.
item.dc:creator: Leah Worthington
item.media:credit: Photo Illustration by Aubrey Trinnaman for The New York Times

item.title: Texas Goes Permitless on Guns, and Police Face an Armed Public
item.description: A new law allowing people to carry handguns without a license has led to more spontaneous shootings, many in law enforcement say.
item.dc:creator: J. David Goodman
item.media:credit: Matthew Busch for The New York Times
item.media:description: Texas is the most populous state to do away with handgun permit requirements.

item.title: Elon Musk Visits Twitter as $44 Billion Deal Nears Completion
item.description: The world’s richest man arrived at Twitter’s San Francisco offices on Wednesday ahead of a Friday deadline to complete the acquisition of the social media service.
item.dc:creator: Ryan Mac and Kate Conger
item.media:credit: Matt Rourke/Associated Press

item.title: Meta Quarterly Earnings: Profit Declines With Losses in Reality Labs
item.description: The social networking company, which is trying to shift into the so-called metaverse, posted falling sales and said it was “making significant changes” to operate more efficiently.
item.dc:creator: Ryan Mac
item.media:credit: Jim Wilson/The New York Times
item.media:description: Facebook renamed itself Meta a year ago, and the company has invested billions into the immersive digital world known as the metaverse.

item.title: A Secret, Failed Oil Deal: How the U.S.-Saudi Relationship Ruptured
item.description: After Saudi leaders pushed to slash oil production despite a visit by President Biden, American officials have been left fuming that they were duped.
item.dc:creator: Mark Mazzetti, Edward Wong and Adam Entous
item.category: Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries
Abdulaziz bin Salman, Prince of Saudi Arabia
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden arriving in Saudi Arabia in July. The administration thought it had secured a promise from the Saudis to keep oil flowing in a bid to stabilize prices.

item.title: Senator Robert Menendez Faces a New Federal Investigation
item.description: The inquiry comes five years after the Justice Department dropped its corruption case against Mr. Menendez, a New Jersey Democrat.
item.dc:creator: Tracey Tully, Benjamin Weiser and William K. Rashbaum

item.title: Evidence ‘Invalidated’ in Explosive Report on Mexico’s 43 Missing Students
item.description: This summer, the government said it had uncovered what happened during the 2014 mass abduction. Arrest warrants quickly followed. But since then, the criminal case and the new account have unraveled.
item.dc:creator: Natalie Kitroeff, Ronen Bergman and Oscar Lopez
item.media:credit: Luis Antonio Rojas for The New York Times

item.title: El caso de los 43 de Ayotzinapa: las pruebas se desmoronaron
item.description: Este verano, el gobierno anunció que había descubierto lo sucedido en el secuestro masivo de los estudiantes en 2014. Se giraron órdenes de aprehensión. Pero desde entonces, el caso penal y el nuevo relato se han venido abajo.
item.dc:creator: Natalie Kitroeff, Ronen Bergman and Oscar Lopez
item.media:credit: Luis Antonio Rojas para The New York Times

item.title: Climate Pledges Are Falling Short, and a Chaotic Future Looks More Like Reality
item.description: With an annual summit next month, the United Nations assessed progress on countries’ past emissions commitments. Severe disruption would be hard to avoid on the current trajectory.
item.dc:creator: Max Bearak
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:credit: Feisal Omar/Reuters
item.media:description: A displaced Somali woman and her children near the carcasses of their livestock, killed by drought, in the country’s Gedo Region in May.

item.title: Prince Harry’s Memoir Is Due in January. How Explosive Will It Be?
item.description: The memoir is expected to be a best seller, but after the queen’s death, some royal experts and industry executives say the project has become risky for Harry.
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth A. Harris and Alexandra Alter
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Stephan De Sakutin
item.media:description: Prince Harry struck a competitive, and lucrative, multi-book deal that had as its main attraction a memoir which he said would be a frank accounting of his life. Since the queen’s death, however, criticizing the royal family has become a riskier proposition.

item.title: The Dos and Don’ts of Living in a Haunted House
item.description: Many Americans believe that their home is inhabited by ghosts, a conviction that researchers attribute to the rise of paranormal-related media, a decline in religious beliefs and the pandemic.
item.dc:creator: Anna Kodé
item.media:credit: Eamon Queeney for The New York Times
item.media:description: Shane Booth in his dining room where he said the bulk of the paranormal activity happens at his home in Benson, N.C.

item.title: Putin Is Onto Us
item.description: When it comes to energy, the West wants five incompatible things at once.
item.dc:creator: Thomas L. Friedman
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Gavriil Grigorov

item.title: What My Father’s Death Taught Me About Living
item.description: The most precious thing my dad gave me was an example of how to live a life devoid of cynicism and pessimism.
item.dc:creator: Lydia Polgreen
item.media:credit: Isabel Seliger

item.title: Most Parents Don’t Favor Abstinence-Only Sex Ed. Why Is the Government Still Funding It?
item.description: It’s 2022, after all.
item.dc:creator: Jessica Grose
item.media:credit: Eleanor Davis

item.title: The Left-Right Divide Might Help Democrats Avoid a Total Wipeout
item.description: Even so, the party is feeling a distinct chill in the air.
item.dc:creator: Thomas B. Edsall
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang/The New York Times

item.title: A Social Media Status Update
item.description: Top social media apps are struggling after a decade of dominance.
item.dc:creator: Kevin Roose
item.media:credit: Jenny Kane/Associated Press
item.media:description: Social media companies are having a troubling year.

item.title: The Trump Subpoena
item.description: The Jan. 6 committee has voted to subpoena former President Donald J. Trump. It’s a momentous move, but it’s not without precedent.
item.dc:creator: Michael Barbaro, Asthaa Chaturvedi, Luke Vander Ploeg, John Ketchum, Dan Powell, Marion Lozano and Chris Wood
item.category: House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack
item.media:credit: Brittany Greeson for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Jan. 6 committee’s decision last week has raised a question: Does former President Donald J. Trump have to comply with a congressional subpoena?

item.title: Some good news on energy
item.description: Renewable sources made up the vast majority of new generating capacity last year, a new report found. But the world’s energy transition still needs to speed up.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Penn
item.media:credit: Bing Guan/Reuters
item.media:description: The Ivanpah Solar Electric Generating System in the Mojave Desert near Nipton, Calif.

item.title: Taylor Swift’s ‘Midnights’: Let’s Discuss
item.description: The blockbuster singer-songwriter’s 10th studio album finds her at a crossroads: Will she continue to reckon with her past, or forge another new path forward?
item.media:credit: Eduardo Munoz/Reuters

item.title: Michigan Jury Convicts Men of Supporting Plot to Kidnap Governor
item.description: The trial in state court followed mixed results in federal court for others accused of scheming to kidnap Gov. Gretchen Whitmer.
item.dc:creator: Mitch Smith
item.media:credit: Ruth Fremson/The New York Times
item.media:description: The defendants were accused of helping Adam Fox, who was convicted in federal court of conspiring to kidnap the governor, whose Covid-19 restrictions the men considered tyrannical.

item.title: Darrell Brooks Found Guilty of Killing 6 in Christmas Parade Attack
item.description: Darrell E. Brooks was convicted of first-degree intentional homicide after driving his car in a rampage through a parade in Waukesha, Wis., in 2021.
item.dc:creator: Julie Bosman
item.media:credit: Mary Mathis for The New York Times
item.media:description: A man placed flowers as a memorial to those killed at a holiday parade in Waukesha, Wis., in November 2021.

item.title: Most Hospitalized Monkeypox Patients in the U.S. Were H.I.V.-Positive
item.description: “Monkeypox and H.I.V. have collided,” a C.D.C. researcher said.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A scan showing monkeypox particles (red) found within an infected cell, cultured in the laboratory at the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases.

item.title: Tens of Thousands in Iran Mourn Mahsa Amini, Whose Death Set Off Protests
item.description: While the security forces cracked down on demonstrations across the country, state media reported a deadly attack on a mosque in the southern city of Shiraz, adding to the atmosphere of tension.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi and Cora Engelbrecht
item.media:credit: Eurovision Social Network/Via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A screen grab from a video posted on Wednesday showed Iranian mourners marching toward Aichi Cemetery in Saghez, Mahsa Amini’s hometown in the northwestern province of Kurdistan.

item.title: Do Statins Increase the Risk of Diabetes?
item.description: These cholesterol-lowering medications have gotten a bad rap. Here’s why.
item.dc:creator: Jyoti Madhusoodanan
item.media:credit: Aileen Son for The New York Times

item.title: Do Antidepressants Work for Severe PMS?
item.description: Premenstrual dysphoric disorder, or PMDD, is an extreme and often debilitating form of PMS that can be tricky to manage. Here’s what treatments work.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Rabkin Peachman
item.media:credit: Eric Helgas for The New York Times

item.title: Are Earbuds Damaging My Hearing?
item.description: And if so, are they more harmful than other headphone styles?
item.dc:creator: Hannah Seo
item.media:credit: Getty Images

item.title: Night Sweats Causes: Experts Explain Why You Sweat In Your Sleep
item.description: There are many possible reasons you might wake up in a pool of perspiration. Here’s how to tell when it should be cause for concern.
item.dc:creator: Alice Callahan
item.media:credit: Eric Helgas for The New York Times

item.title: Celiac Disease Treatment: Are We Close to a Cure?
item.description: Recent advances in understanding the condition have brought a surge of potential therapies to the drug development pipeline.
item.dc:creator: Alice Callahan
item.media:credit: Eric Helgas for The New York Times

item.title: Aurelio Voltaire is the Goth Martha Stewart
item.description: Through his “Gothic Homemaking” YouTube series, Aurelio Voltaire has become a lifestyle guru to people who embrace spookiness in all seasons.
item.dc:creator: Molly Fitzpatrick
item.media:credit: Olivia Crumm for The New York Times
item.media:description: Since 2016, Aurelio Voltaire has filmed 108 episodes (and one trailer) for his YouTube series “Gothic Homemaking,” which he started as a way to document his progress transforming his East Village apartment into an occult oasis.

item.title: How to Solve Hard Crosswords
item.description: Friday, Saturday and Sunday bring some of the hardest puzzles of the week.
item.dc:creator: Jackie Frere and Isaac Aronow
item.media:credit: Thomas Merceron
